title_sort: reuben farwell to walt whitman, 10 may 1864
title: Reuben Farwell to Walt Whitman, 10 May 1864
text: Dear Comrad[Comrade]Yours received last night. and need I tell you that I am unwilling to answer yours. When there is so much stir & confusionNo I will tell you that we are about to leave this Camp for better or worseTo the front I suppose is the place of our destinationLast Night we went to the wharf to get each a horse But I had to returne[return] to camp with out one because there were not enough to supply us allThis Morning we the Veterans or old Soldiers have to take horses & the New recruits remain in CampWe will be sent a way from here before to Morrow Night I think, which would suit me very well for I am sick of staying around this cursed place Â I will try & see you before I cross the long Bridge but if I can not get a chance, I hope you will write whenever convient[convenient]Give my best respects to the Boys on Ward. A.Believe me ever Your FriendReuben FarwellI will try & write you when to the front In hast Reuben Farwell to Walt Whitman, 10 May 1864
